'''Earl Gaines''' (August 19, 1935 – December 31, 2009)<ref name="Dead"/> was an [[United States|American]] [[soul blues]] and [[electric blues]] [[singing|singer]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Jason Ankeny |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/earl-gaines-mn0000153621/biography |title=Earl Gaines | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> Born in [[Decatur, Alabama]], he sang lead vocals on the [[hit single]] "It's Love Baby (24 Hours a Day)", credited to [[Louis Brooks]] and his Hi-Toppers,<ref name="Dead">{{cite web |url=http://www.thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2009b.html |title=Earl Gaines |author=|publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |accessdate=April 30, 2010}}</ref> before undertaking a low-key solo career. In the latter capacity he had minor success with "The Best of Luck to You" (1966) and "Hymn Number 5" (1973). Noted as the best [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] singer from Nashville, Gaines was also known for his lengthy career.<ref name="Musicrow">{{cite web |url=http://www.musicrow.com/2010/01/nashville-rb-star-earl-gaines-1935-2009/ |title=Earl Gaines obituary |author=Oermann, Robert K.|publisher=Musicrow.com |accessdate=April 30, 2010}}</ref>

==Biography==
After moving from his hometown in his teenage years, and relocating to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Gaines found employment as both a singer and occasional drummer. Via work he did for local [[songwriter]], Ted Jarrett, Gaines moved from singing in [[nightclub|clubs]] to meeting Louis Brooks.  Brooks led the [[instrumental]] Hi-Toppers, who had a [[recording contract]] with the [[Excello Records|Excello]] [[record label|label]]. Their subsequent joint [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]], "It's Love Baby (24 Hours a Day)," peaked at #2 on the [[United States|US]] [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]] in 1955. It was Gaines biggest hit, but his name was not credited on the [[Gramophone record|record]].<ref name="AMG"/>

Breaking away from the confines of the group, Gaines became part of the 1955 R&B Caravan of Stars, with [[Bo Diddley]], [[Big Joe Turner]], and [[Etta James]].<ref name="Tennessean">{{cite web |url=http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2009/12/31/rb-legend-earl-gaines-dies-at-age-74/ |title=Earl Gaines obituary |author=Zettler, Linda|publisher=Tennessean.com |accessdate=April 30, 2010}}</ref> Their tour culminated with an appearance at [[New York City|New York]]'s [[Carnegie Hall]].<ref name="AMG"/>  Without any tangible success, Gaines recorded for the [[Champion Records|Champion]] and Poncello labels for another few years, as well as joining [[Bill Doggett]]'s band as lead vocalist. In 1963, he joined [[Bill "Hoss" Allen]]'s repertoire of artists, and by 1966 had issued the [[album]], ''The Best of Luck to You'', seeing the title track reach the [[Top 40]] in the US R&B chart. He appeared on the [[television program]] ''[[The !!!! Beat]]'', and later released material for [[King Records (USA)|King]] and [[Sound Stage 7]], including his [[cover version]] of "Hymn Number 5".<ref name="AMG"/> Recordings made between 1967 and 1973 for [[De Luxe Records|De Luxe]] were reissued in 1998.<ref name="Musicrow"/> On many of his De Luxe recordings in the late 1960s and early 1970s, Gaines was backed by [[Abu Talib (musician)|Freddy Robinson]]'s orchestra.<ref name="Wirz"/>

In 1975, Gaines recorded "Drowning On Dry Land" for [[Ace Records (US)|Ace]], before leaving the [[music industry]] for almost a decade and a half, to work as a truck driver.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Soul"/> He finally re-emerged in 1989 with the album ''House Party''.<ref name="Musicrow"/>

In the 1990s Gaines worked with [[Roscoe Shelton]] and [[Clifford Curry]].<ref name="Soul">{{cite web|url=http://www.soulbluesmusic.com/earlgaines.htm |title=Earl Gaines |publisher=Soulbluesmusic.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>  On Appaloosa Records, Gaines issued ''I Believe in Your Love'' (1995), and in 1997 he reunited with Curry and Shelton for a collaborative [[live album]].<ref name="AMG"/> He released ''Everything’s Gonna Be Alright'' in 1998.<ref name="Musicrow"/> Gaines work was on the 2005 [[Grammy Award]] winning ''[[Night Train to Nashville|Night Train To Nashville: Music City Rhythm & Blues, 1945–1970]]'', an exhibit at the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum]].<ref name="Tennessean"/> His own albums ''The Different Feelings of Blues and Soul'' (2005) and ''Nothin’ But the Blues'' (2008) followed, the latter released on the [[Ecko Records|Ecko]] label.<ref name="Musicrow"/><ref name="Soul"/>

In late 2009 Gaines had to cancel a [[concert tour]] of [[Europe]] due to ill health,<ref name="Tennessean"/> and he died in Nashville on the last day of that year, at the age of 74.<ref name="Dead"/> 

He is not to be confused with [[Steve Gaines|Steven Earl Gaines]], a fellow American musician.
